abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Guayaquil and Guayas Water
            Supply Project in Ecuador. The project was designed to
            increase Guayaquil low water service coverage and to improve
            the Municipal Water Supply Company performance to handle an
            increased customer base in a more efficient and financially
            sound manner. The project's physical objectives have
            been largely achieved. The Bank's performance was
            deficient in identification preparation, and appraisal work.
            Lessons from the unsatisfactory first project were not
            sufficiently absorbed, and the difficulty to strengthen the
            water supply company was vastly underestimated. The overall
            performance of the Borrower was deficient, particularly in
            1989-91 after disbursements were suspended. The project
            outcome is rated as highly unsatisfactory. The project
            provided several important lessons for water supply
            operations: 1) Institutional strengthening of public
            companies should not be attempted when there is a lack of an
            enabling political and institutional environment that
            broadly influences the company; 2) Establish clear and
            quantifiable objectives and goals from the beginning; 3)
            During the preparation stage ensure full commitment of the
            beneficiaries and assess their willingness to pay, as
            integral part of the financial viability of the project; 4)
            Introduce private management (concession) as an alternative
            to improving water supply systems; 5) Well staffed and
            trained project executing unit, with adequate autonomy to
            make operational decisions about project implementation must
            be in place at the time project execution begins.
